creator: max.wach

content:
Please be more specific about what does "emails cannot be sent" mean. Post a screenshot of the error message you get, if any, and of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, so we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

In particular, if you're using a VPN, disable it and see whether that makes the problem go away. If it does, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN.
creator: DavidGG

content:
In the menu bar, choose View > Folders > Folder Pane Header if not already ticked, to make that visible. Then, click on the '···' button to the right of the '+ New Message' button in that pane to display a list of options. One of the options available there near the bottom should be Hide Local Folders, which you have probably ticked, select it to untick it and make the Local Folders appear in the folder pane.

The following article shows the Folder Pane Header and explains the options available there:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/new-thunderbird-115-supernova#w_look-and-feel-improvements-new-message-button-get-messages-folder-pane-options-meatball-menu
creator: DavidGG

content: Is this a snapshot of active profile or the prior profile? I see you also have a default.esr profile. Did you check to verify that Local Folders aren't hidden (see the three dots to right of 'new message' button). Another place to look is clicking the sbd entries as some local folders may be there. The msf entries can be ignored, as they are just indexes that thunderbird automatically reconstructs. If the folders are actually missing, you can coy them from wherever they are to the Mail\Local Folders folder when thunderbird isn't running and then restart.
creator: davidsk

content: The default address books are abook.sqlite (Personal Address Book) and history.sqlite (Collected Addresses). They can be copied into a profile, with TB closed, overwriting existing files. Other address books have the same extension and can be imported from Tools/Import.
creator: sfhowes

The tbkeys-lite addon makes the J key the same as Next Message by default, but you can investigate further to suit your purposes.

https://github.com/wshanks/tbkeys

content: I deleted the account and attempted to re-add it. At first, I got an error message saying there was an error logging in. Then I remembered that I got the same message when I added the account the first time along with some kind of OAUTH error. So I changed that to Autodetect and then the email account was added. Went to the folder list and it was populated so I subscribed all folders successfully.
creator: davehuong

content:
The tags are stored on the IMAP server if the server supports keywords, but not all servers do. In the case of gmail, a tag applied in TB on one computer is displayed in TB on another device, as long as both devices have the same set of tags defined. Keep in mind that gmail uses the term 'label' in a different sense from TB's tags.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Tags#IMAP
creator: sfhowes

content:
BUT, BUT, BUT… The string you appear to be looking for is not the string that appears in the message… The latter has a colon between "Client" and the number…

That said, if global search doesn't work even when you search for the right string, see whether this could fix the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/rebuilding-global-database
creator: DavidGG

content: Check your Account Settings > Junk Settings. If this is an IMAP account, it could be that Thunderbird is trying to use the wrong folder for this. You may tell it to use a folder that may already be available on the server for junk/spam by selecting Other, then choosing the right folder there.
creator: DavidGG

content: I may not be understanding something here, because it looks to me that the answer to your question is in the screenshots you posted and that you appear to have already noticed, which is that spurious 127.0.0-1.1 IMAP folder showing the contents of what appears to have been a Gmail account including an All Mail folder taking up about 38 GB of disk space all by itself, and which doesn't seem to correspond to any of the mail accounts you currently have in Thunderbird, hence Thunderbird not showing that…

content:
Ak máte ešte prístup k starému Thunderbirdu s poštou, tak odporúčam tento postup: Zo starého PROFILU Thunderbirdu prekopírujte do nového PROFILU Thunderbirdu celý priečinok Mail (Ak mate prístup POP3) a priečinok ImapMail (ak mate prístup IMAP). Tam je všetko to čo potrebujete - všetka pošta a nastavenie účtov. Takto mate teraz skopírovanú poštu a nastavenia účtov. Pokiaľ spustite Thunderbird, tak uvidíte späť svoju starú poštu. C:\Users\<Windows user name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<Profile name>\ http://kb.mozillazine.org/Profile_folder_-_Thunderbird#Windows_Vista.2C_7.2C_8.1_and_10

POZOR: - všetky tieto kopírovania a premenovania sa musia vykonávať pri ukončenom (vypnutom) Thunderbirde !!! = Import kontaktov je takisto jednoduchý v prípade, že máte ešte prístup k starému Thunderbirdu so starým profilom. V starom Thunderbirde: Thunderbird - Nástroje - Adresár - Nástroje - EXPORT - a vytvoriť si súbor *.ldif a potom v novom Thunderbirde Thunderbird - Nástroje - Adresár - Nástroje - IMPORT - Adresáre a tu mu ponúknuť ten vytvorený *.ldif súbor.
creator: Ansamb

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
Maybe I'm misunderstanding, but moving thunderbird by copying folders isn't the general approach. Instead we recommend copying the profile.

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk
